div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The L massol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus, ot to the Manager, "Egyptian Gazette" Alexandria. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello." The climate of Cyprus is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook &Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: DISCONTENT IN TURKEY
div.p: DISCONTENT IN TURKEY In an interesting article on the present state o' affairs in Turkey, an occasional correspondent of the "Times” writes that perhaps the most potent cause of the discontent is to be found in the character of the men who are now sent to the provinces as governors-general. The old type of Vali, &c., was frequently brutal and corrupt but he had generally served a long apprentive-ship in smaller posts, knew his business, and understood the people and their wants. Since the appointments to these posts have passed from the hands of the Porte, which, with all its shortcomings, had some sense of responsibility, into the hands of Palace favourites, they have been used to reward their friends, and have been given to men who possess the vices of their predecessors and none of their virtues. They are just as corrupt, just as brutal, although perhaps in a less downright way, and in addition they have had no experience of life in the provinces and no training in administrative work. Hardly less fruitful of discontent has been the almost incredible mismanagement of everything connected with finance. The taxes collected in the provinces are sent to the capital and only a very small portion ands its way back to be used for the benefit of the taxpayers. Of the remainder, a certain amount is devoted to expenditure which is more or less productive, but no inconsiderable part of it either disappears into the pockets of corrupt officials or is spent in ways that cannot by any possibility be regarded as productive, such as the purchase of the ships of war which lie rotting in the golden Horn and in the Dardanelles, or the maintenance of the huge army of spies who swarm in Constantinople and to a less extent in other cities. It is no wonder that the unfortunate peasant, who feels his taxes as a crushing burden, should begin to complain when he sees that he gets no return from them, and that even the officials are left for months at a time without receiving a penny of salary from the Government, and are thus forced to live by robbing the people.

The clique at the Palace (continues the correspondent) is apt to take credit to itself for the great extension of the railway system which has taken place under its auspices. No one would deny that railways are a good thing for the country or that the districts through which they pass have been made more prosperous by

them. But the corrupt way in which the concessions have been given has brought it about that in almost every case the price paid has | been out of all proportion to the usefulness of the line, and, moreover, this price is paid in the shape of kilometric guarantees so arranged that, the less work the railways do, the greater is the profit which they make. As if it were not enough to bribe the railways in this way to do as little as possible for the development of the country, every difficulty is put in their way when they try to do anything. Not only are roads not built to enable the peasant to bring bis produce to the stations, but no Turkish subject is | allowed to travel about the country without the permission of the authorities, and this permission | is practically never given to Armenians, who are the keenest traders, and is very rarely given to Turks, Greek and Jews enjoy a little more liberty in this respect, but even for them it is difficult to move about and look after their business. The result is, of course, partly to prevent trade and partly to throw what trade there is into the hands of foreign subjects. To show to what an extent this mad system is carried, it may be mentioned that a short time ago the Anatolian Railway suggested to Government modifications of the passport regulations, and assured the Government that, if they were adopted, they would increase the receipts of the railway by many thousands of pounds and save the Treasury a corresponding sum in kilometric guarantees. The modifications would not have made it any easier for undesirable persons to escape the vigilance of the police, but the government, none the less refused to consider them. In short, the railway police of Yildiz, if there is a policy at all, is to spend as much on the lines and to get as little return as possible.

There is thus little difficulty in understanding the discontent of all who live by trade or by agriculture-that is to say, of the great majority of the population. The difficulty is even less when we come to consider the discontent of the educated classes who supply officials to the Administration and officers to the army. Their movements are dogged at every step by the spies on whom such a large proportion of the national revenue is wasted. Their reading is subjected to a censorship of which it would be hard to say whether it is the more stupid or the more tyrannical. The revival of Tarkish literature, which showed so much promise three or four decades ago, has been crushed, and the works of Shinasi Sadullah Pasha, Kemal Bey, and others, of which educated Turks are so proud, have been placed on the index and can only be read in stealth. Neither in the army nor in the Administration is there any such thing as promotion by merit. To get on, one must secure the protection of some official with influence at the Palace, and the only sure way of winning such protection is either to buy it or to turn informer against one's comrades. Large numbers of young men succumb to this temptation, and the evil has reached such dimensions that & Turk runs the risk of exile and ruin for every word or action that can be twisted into a sign of disaffection. It has been known, for example, that schoolboys have been banished from the capital for giving a light for his cigarette to a man sitting beside them in a tramcar, who happened to be, although the boys could hardly have known it, & servant of the Heir to the Throne, with whom it is treason to have any intercourse. The encouragement given to informers has produced a class of blackmailers who live and flourish by threatening to make trouble at the Palace for any one who refuses to pay them not to do so..

There is not an educated class in any éountry which would not become restive under such treatment, and with the Turks the discontent is increased by the humiliation they feel on account of the ineptitude shown by the Government, both in its management of home affairs and in its dealings with foreign Powers ; at the way in which abuses are tolerated until they invite, almost compel, that European interference which is so distasteful to nearly every Tark; and at the way in which that interference is met, when it does come, by the people who pull the strings at the Palace, and whose only idea of diplomacy is to begin by rejecting even the most moderate demands, and to end by accepting even the most extravagant. Of course, the educated class in Turkey is a very small one, but it would be a mistake to regard it on that account of little or no importance. Apart from other considerations, their feelings and opinions are not without influence on the rest of the population, and the Government is doing a great deal to extend this influence by its practice of exiling into the provinces everybody whom it suspects of advanced views. The number of people who are said to have been exiled in this way exceeds all belief. But, when every allowance has been made for exaggeration, the exiles have been numerous enough to have an effect on public opinion in every part of the Empire. It is a well known fact that there are districts where practically the whole of the Effendi class is composed of men expelled from Constantinople on account of their opinions Many of these men manage to keep in touch with friends in the capital and with friends abroad, and to play the part of missionaries of disaffection, and there is even reason to think that influences of this kind had something to do with bringing about the recent incidents at Bitlis and elsewhere.

div.head: A Thaw Fortune.
div.p: Mr. Stephen Dows Thaw, the presumptive heir to a fortune of £6,000,000, and a nephew of Mr. Harry Thaw, has left Pittsburg for Syria, as a missionary for the Presbyterian Church.

div.head: Births and Deaths.
div.p: 530 births, of which fifteen were of European parentage, and 471 deaths, of which fourteen were Europeans, were registered in Cairo during the week ending the 9th inst., 308 of the deaths were of children under five years of age.

div.head: The "Olivemoor."
div.p: Up to the time of going to press no further news concerning the situation of the "Olivemoor" is obtainable. As we reported yesterday pumping operations were commenced, and these have been continued incessantly, work being proceeded with thrònghont the night.

div.head: A New Paper
div.p: We understand that Capt. Jorge Nelken Waldberg, who has already gained considerably notoriety by the now defunct "Oriental Truth," is about to issue a new paper under the name of the "Petit Journal Egyptien." We wish the new adventure as complete a success as its predecessor.

div.head: San Francesco School.
div.p: The re-opening of the San Francesco School at El Menayer, Alexandria, under the direction of the Franciscan Fathers, will take place on Monday next 16th instant, special attention is paid to teaching the English language, in which lessons are given daily by a certificated teacher.

div.head: The Pôrte and Armenia
div.p: The curious fact is revealed in the annual report of the British and Foreign Bible Society that in the last consignment of Bibles received at Bagdad all the maps had been torn out in which the name Armenia occurred. The dragoman of the British Consulate explained that the name of Armenia on a map is forbidden in Turkey.

div.head: Restaurant Car Destroyed.
div.p: On Tuesday evening the restanrant car run. ning between Luxor and Assouan was destroyed by fire. The fire broke out in the kitchen of the car and rapidly spread, and only four chairs were saved, the car being a total wreck. Much excitement was caused among the pas. sengers, none of whom, however, received any injury.

div.head: Savoy Palace Hotel.
div.p: The Savoy Palace Hotel, which re-opened on the 1st inst. is receiving the best patronage, and the many improvements which they have carried out are met with approval on all sides. Special features of the hotel are the two new restaurants which they have opened, and which, we are confident, will be patronised during the coming season by the elite of Alexandria for after theatre suppers, which is one of the specialities of this hotel, while the bar is one of the best equipped of Alexandria.

div.head: Big Property Sale.
div.p: In view of the various rumours and pessimistic reports which have been occasioned by the existing financial crisis, it is interesting to note any proof that the price of suburban land is by no means on the decline. We might cite as an instance the sale of • 70,000 pics at Halte Laurens, in the neighbourhood of the Bean Rivaye Hotel, at the rate of P.T. 96. This land has been acquired by a syndicate consisting of Messrs. Prazzica, Zombos and Avlanitis.

div.head: INVESTMENT IN EGYPT.
div.p: DEFENCE OF THE BANKS.
Sir W.F. Miéville, K.C.M.G., contributes the following article to the "Financial Review of Reviews" under the beading of "Egypt as a field for the Bona Fide investor.” :—

That an unsatisfactory situation would be created on the Bourses of Alexandria andCairo was foreseen by attentive onlookers who were in Egypt during the past winter, for not only was it difficult to keep count of the new companies launched almost daily, but it was practically impossible during the rush of flotations to estimate the real value of each undertaking. Promoters and company-mongers not ünnaturally took advantage of this rapid flotation of companies to foist on a confiding, excited public many concerns at which old residents ominously shook their heads. One of the pitiful incidents of the recent over-speculation was due to the fact that brokers' touts induced petty shopkeepers and others, knowing nothing of stocks and shares, to buy for a rise; of course while markets continued buoyant all went well, but when the fall came both the gambling shopkeepers and, in many cases, the persuasive broker, found themselves very hard hit.

The highly excitable nature of many of the numerous newly-fledged members of the local Exchanges; the frequently-repeated stories, daily heard, of hitherto penurious, or at least but modestly endowed, gentlemen popping into affluence; and the gambling propensities of so many of the well-to-do of the European colonies, created an extraordinary atmospere of speculation, and in this medium the second cause of the Egyptian troubles, namely: the building-land boom, was generated. It began in this wise: advantageous offers were made by speculators to all and sundry of those who were possessed of building plots in good residential quarters of Cairo or Alexandria, and their suburbs, and when, for a plot worth ten years ago but £2,000 or £3,000, the owner was bid £10,000 the temptation was great to realise the substantial profit. His land, often within forty-eight hours, would probably be resold for £15,000; a week or a month later, it would again change hands at £20,000 and finally be bought at a still further enhanced figure by some new ur. banlands company. In cases like this the middlemen grew rich and the ultimate loss, it the last price was too ridiculously high, fell on the company, i.e., on the poor pigeons, its shareholders. I know of actual cases where properties were sold at the height of the boom for ten times their first sale price, though, of course, all urban sites did not rise in value to the same degree, owing to the difference in situation and a multitude of other reasons. In another category of cases the last buyers, being either too grasping or too badly stricken with the prevalent money-making' fever, failed to re-sell their plots before the Bourse troubles became acute, while even some of those—individuals as well as companies—who did sell before the crisis arrived were forced to take back what they reasonably imagined they had disposed of at a handsome profit, for, when the pinch came, they discovered the purchasers to be next door to insolvent. Inasmuch as in most cases the agreement was to pay for the purchase by instalments, with but a small sum cash down. it made the gnashing of these sales casier, and obviously rescission was the only course to adopt even though the recovered property was temporarily unmarketable owing to the extraordinary scarcity of hard cash. Curiously interesting is it to note that the Bourse crisis. which ended for the nonce the building boom was itself precipitated by the building land gamble, for Bourse speculators had joined in the blind rush first for town plots and then for suburban sites. The germs of the speculative fever must indeed have floated still farther afield for even a few British investors appear to have been infected and consequently, it is to be feared, have suffered in pocket. Yet it did not permeate all classes, for many residents, and many old land mortgage companies, like the one with which I myself am connected, prudently fought shy of touching building plots. Happily also, men in responsible financial positions, such as the managers of the principal banks, early grasped the true significance of the position and by their timely action aided in bringing matters to a crisis ere the evil had become a fatally cancerous growth. Several local gentlemen hold that the measures taken by the Banks were both too general and too severe; but there are maladies where half measures are worse than useless, and this, I maintain, was such a case, and the Banks' action, though undoubtedly drastic, was, under the circumstances, not only wise but necessary.

That in the last three months a most uncomfortable and even anxious time, aggravated by general tightness in the money market, has been passed in financial circles in Egypt is incontestable, but the comments of the London correspondent of the "Scotsinan," quoted in the July number of this "Review," seem somewhat wide of the mark. He writes of "a meeting of the leading banks... at Alexandria at which it was decided, subject to the sanction of their respective directors, to contribute a fund amounting to a million sterling" ; and he adds : "What comes of efforts to bolster up artificially an inherently unsound speculative edifice has been proved on more than one occasion in the case of the South African gold share market."

New seeing that Egypt differs essentially from South Africa in that in Egypt the economic condition of the country is absolutely sound the analogy was unfortunate. And while admitting the embarrassments of the Bourse speculators following on a period of unaccustomed influx of capital and consequent prosperity, I must take exception to the phrase an inherently unsound speculative edifice.”

div.head: BONAPARTE IN EGYPT.
div.p: LATE HAJI BROWNE'S BOOK.

Our first impression on opening the late Haji Browne's recent production was that we were about to enjoy a new historical work upon an important period of Egyptian history which has so far been somewhat inadequately dealt with,; we thought to find some discussion upon the events which led to Napoleon's dash into Egypt, some accurate description of the events which took place there during his occupation and some criticism of his hasty, retirement | But we were doomed to disappointment, for historically the book is of little value ; what there is of history in it is of the petty order, and lacks width of imagination ; in fact it all seems to be drawn from the contemporary writer, Gabarty, who was more of a philosopher than an historian, and who interested himself in the French occupation from the point of view of ethnical rather than historical study. The present author acknowledges practically no other source than Gabarty, on whose merits he en-larges, even to the extent of making a typical digression at one period into his history and personal character. The reason why he relies so much on. Gabarty unfolds itself as we get into the book ; for Gabarty took the same view of the French invaders as Haji Browne is now doing, and studied it with the same end in view, namely to prove that the Egyptians were an ill-used race and that had they received & reasonable degree of sympathy they would to-day have been very different to what they are.

The book then is not, properly speaking, historical, though of course there is a certain amount of historical detail included; it is rather a study in racial character, and Napoleon is merely the peg on which the study is hung. It is the old question of the opposition of east and west once more; Egypt is the fighting ground, as it were, of the problem, and Haji Browne is one more champion on the eastern side.

Before, however, we commence to criticise his attitude on the subject we feel bound to say that his work is difficult to deal with in any concise way because as a book it is greatly lacking in conciseness. The author seems to mix up the important and the unimportant, he digresses on little details of no moment and omits facts of pre-eminent weight. Indeed, it is only necessary to say that the period from the rise of Mahomet Ali to the French expedition to Fashoda is treated in a single short chapter, while the few years of the French invasion occupy some fifteen, and we see that the author interests himself in history only so far as it lends proof to his contentions.

We would not, however deny that the author is making a genuine attempt in this book to solve the almost insoluble difficulty of the opposition of the eastern to the western aspect of life, and we readily admit that Napoleon made a great error in his treatment of the Egyptians, especially in his attitude to their religious scruples ; but it is questionable, we think, whether Napoleon was so lacking in intellect and foresight as Haji Browne makes him out to have been ; after all Napoleon was not a man who cared what future generations should suffer so long as he gained his point at the moment. But the question is whether Napoleon's oppressions really did so much to destroy the Egyptian national character, or whether it has not always been their inability to defend and govern themselves that has made the Egyptians the prey of a succession of invaders; it is a matter of history that this has always been their case and it is only in recent years, comparatively speaking, that Europeans have been their governors.

div.head: INDIA AND EGYPTIAN COTTON.
div.p: Writing from Calcutta to the United States Department of Commerce, Consul-General W. H. Michael sends the following report on the cotton exports and cotton crop of India : "the raw cotton exported from India during 1906-7 was 7,396,591 cwt., which exceeded the quantity exported the year previously by only a few hundredweight (5,600), but the value was £14,218,910, or greater by £401,802. The principal buyers of the crop were Japan, which took 1,728,958cwt. ; Germany, 1,648,349cwt, and Belgium, 1,100,969cwt. Italy, France, and Austria-Hungary were were purchasers in much smaller amounts, and England took less than 6 per cent. of the total, which, it is understood here, she re-exported. The acreage under cotton this year in India is larger by 1,272,000 acres than last year, a part, being planted to Egyptian cotton, which is reported as doing well. Some of this variety of cotton, grown in Sind, was marketed last year at good prices, and great hopes are placed on its future production. About half of the raw cotton produced is now required by Indian mills, which have enlarged their capacity during the last year, especially for the production of piece goods of a higher grade, most of a higher grade, most of which the mills expect to sell in the local market for home consumption.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Moss Liner "Khephren" sailed from Malta yesterday and is due here on Saturday evening with passengers, mails and general cargo.

div.head: RAILWAY FATALITY.
div.p: (FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT)
Suez, Wednesday.

Yesterday afternoon a crowd of native coolies were coming up to Suez from Port Tewfik as usual, by the 5.40 p.m. train, and one of them, aged about 18 years, in order to avoid paying the fare of five milliems, travelled on the footboard, from which he fell under the train which was at the time going at full speed. He was cut in two, the wheels passing over his chest.

div.head: TURKISH TRANSPORT.
div.p: The Turkish transport "Assyr” from Hodeidah with time-expired men, arrived at Suez three days ago, but is still lying in the Roads owing to them not having a sufficient sum to pay the Canal dues.
In the meantime, the steamer is kept in strict quarantine.

div.head: MOTOR CARS FOR THE DESERT.
div.p: SIRDAR'S EXPERIMENTS AT DUNBAR.

During his stay at Danbar the Sirdar, Sir Francis Wingate, has been carrying out further experiments with a view of obtaining a type of motor car suitable for use in the Egyptian desert. Over a portion of the sands at Belhaven, near Dunbar, last week tests were made with & motor-car which has been specially constructed for Sir Francis. | The car, which has wheels of exceptional dimensions, was first taken over a stretch of very heavy sand, into which it sank from 9 in. to 12in., and it got along well at a speed of about six miles an hour. The next test was over a stretch of the heaviest sand, and after proceeding some distance the wheels skidded, and the car had to be extricated by the aid of planks. In the third test the car again became embedded in a sand bed, but was soon got out, On the whole the tests were considered to be! eminently satisfactory, as the conditions were much more severe than would be experienced in Egypt. The Sirdar witnessed the trials.
EGYPT'S MINING REGION.

The Alexandria Correspondent to the “Ti-mes Engineering Supplement" writes :- The commission appointed by the Egyptian Government to investigate the policy of the mining region in the eastern desert has presented its report. The report, together with the draft law formulated by the Ministry, was the subject of debate in one of the last sittings of the Legislative Council in Cairo. Mr. Wells, Inspector of Mines, and Mr. Brunyate, Khedivial Counsel in the Ministry of Justice, were attached as technical advisers to the commission. The decree submitted to the Legislative Coun, cil covers by definition the area bounded on the north by Suez, on the south by Wady Halfa, on the east by the Red Sea, and on the west by the cultivated lands extending from the Nile valley. The mining area "par excellence" within this district lies between Keneh and Wady Halfa; and within this restricted area again the majority of the active mines that are now being worked lie facing the provinces of Keneh and Assuan. It was in this zone that an exhaustive survey was made of the roads and communications uniting the mines with the principal railway and river centres of both provinces, and as a consequence of that survey it was finally decided to select Edfu as the central radiating point. This place will, therefore, become the headquarters of the mining police, and, doubtless, too, of other future administrative adjuncts necessitated by the development of the mining industry. The Government's technical advisers are fully convinced from reports and various sources of information respecting the configuration of the country that not only are there no existing ways of communication with the provinces adjacent, but that there is a total absence of wells. Mining enterprise must therefore remain in partial abeyance in this zone, at least for the present. To reach this secondary zone the most practicable means is to travel across the principal region already defined. For this reason no other administrative centre besides Edfu is considered expedient, as yet at any rate. The minng police force will be attached direct to the Ministry of the Interior and will I be entitled to a judiciary police.

div.head: BOURSE AND BANKING.
div.p: EXCLUSION OF THE PRESS.

The adjourned extraordinary meeting of the shareholders of the Bourse and Banking Co. of Egypt, Ltd., will be held this afternoon at four o'clock. The fact that the Press has been excluded, as has been amply evidenced by the negative answer to our request for admission, is hardly in favour of the intentions of the directors towards their shareholders, but we can assure our readers that means have been taken to report the proceedings of the meeting with accuracy, and in detail.

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION.
div.p: AN AUDITOR'S INSPECTION.

Egypt will shortly be visited by Mr. J. Gibson, the Assistant Comptroller and Audi. tor to the British Government, He will make a local inspection here of the accounts of the Army of Occupation in Egypt. Mr. Gibson who will be accompanied by Mr. H. N. Bunbury, of the Exchequer and Audit Department, sailed from Marseilles on Tuesday, the 10th inst., and will return early in January next. He will also visit British East Africa, Uganda, Zanzibar, Cyprus and Gibraltar with the object of inspecting the accounts of those places and the work of the local audit offices, for the supervision of which the Comptroller and Auditor General is responsible. He will also take the opportunity of making a local inspection en route, of the accounts of his Majesty's naval and military establishments/at Malta, Gibraltar, and of certain Consular posts in addition to his inspection in Egypt.

div.head: THE EGYPTIANS' LOVE OF DETAIL.
div.p: The Cairo Engineering Correspondent of the "Financial News” writes :

"British-manufacturers should bear in mind that, now that the Egyptian pative as a claus is rapidly becoming a man of money, and consequently a purchaser of machinery, it is worth their while to study his peculiarities and prejudices, and notable among these is his weakness for long and minute, and even what may appear irrelevant, information. A very I great deal of business is done by our sontinental competitors, simply because their local agents not only have a thorough knowledge of French, but are Anent in Arabic, and are willing to converse in a friendly and even intimate manner on all sorts of subjects which may, or may not, have.& direct bearing on the order which they are desirous of obtaining. Firms at home, too, should be careful not to be casual, and, above all, brief in the printed matter and estimates which they send ont. In many ways the Egyptian purchaser, though his orders are sometimes large, is still a tyro in modern business methods. Even when his order is a small one he is glad to have voluminous documents relating to it and to other things which he may possibly require some day, and with the more pictures the better. Line drawings, too, although in nine cases out of ten he cannot understand them, create a profound and lasting impression. The French and German agents here understand this peculiarity of the Egyptian purchaser thoroughly, and a large amount of their business can be traced to the fact that they habitually put into practice the suggestions I have given you above."

SEPTEMBER SKYE-MEETING.
Owners are reminded that entries will close on Monday next 16th inst, at 6 p.m.
Ibrahim Fouad Pasha has arrived at Caito, and left for San Stefano.

We are pleased to be able to announce that Sir Ayckland Colvin has now recovered from the illness from which he has been suffering for some weeks past. We understand he is now quite convalescent, and hopes to be able to attend to business affairs shortly.
Dr. Ruffer has arrived at Berlin, where he will assist with Dr. Graham and De. Bitter at the International Medical Congress.
Mr. Mikajl Nicol has been appointed asist-ant director of the Zoological garden, at Guizeh.
Hassan Bey Mazloum who arrived yesterday from Europe to San Stephano, has resumed his duties as Private Secretary to Lord Edward Cecil Pasha, in the Ministry of Finance.
The Khedive has promoted to the grade of Lewa, Ibrahim Pasha Sabri, general of the Egyptian Army, who will probably retire on pension, and be replaced by Miratai Mohamed Bey Helmi.

div.head: COTTON BILLS OF LADING.
div.p: The Association of Liverpool Clearing Bankers has resolved to put a stop to irregular cotton bills of lading, which are said to have been latterly on the increase. There bills state that the cotton has been shipped or received for shipment," whereas the goods at the time are frequently lying at some interior point.

The conference at which the subject was discussed was attended not only by representatives of the cottón industry, but by Shipowners, underwriters, and bankers and the resolution to take steps against the practice was unanimous."'Phe banks are now asking their clients to use the two classes of bills approved by the conference, viz. a through bi of lading so drawn as to establish the continuity of responsibility of the several carriers from the interior point to the ultimate European or other foreign destination, or a port bill of lading duly signed on behalf of the steamer by the captain or other authorised agent after the receipt of the goods at the port of shipment.

The Association are informing cotton shippers and merchants and buyers of cotton drafts that they do not see their way to continue to accept or make advances against bills of lading of the kind described.

div.head: COTTON WORM
div.p: The result of the operations against the cotton worm for the week ending September 4th is as follows:--
The provinces of Assiout, Beni Souef, Fayoum, Gbiza, Minia and Kena remain immune.
In Behera 218 feddans in 9-villages were infected and cleared.
In Dakahlia 62 fed dans in 61 villages were infected and cleared.
In Gharbia 1325 feddans in 108 villages were infected and cleared. 1
In Kalioubia 346 feddans in 103 villages were infested and cleared.
In Menoufia 22k. feddans in 9 villages were infected and cleared. -
In Sharkia 199. feddans in 3 villages were infected and cleared.
Throughout the country 2,152 feddans in 216 villages were infected and cleared.

div.head: CURIOUS CANAL AT ASSOUAN.
div.p: A canal of a curious type has been built below the Assouan Dam in extension of the Egyptian irrigation system. In order to irrigate the district between Assopan, and Edfu it is necessary, to lift the flood stream by pomps before irrigation can proceed, and the water thus lifted is thrown into a service reservoir. From this reservoir a steel canal has been built which distributes the water into culverts, whence it flows to water the land. The steel canal, the "Morning Post”, explains, was laid down in the desert like.gigantic cheese scoop a mile long, semi-circular in form, and about twenty feet broad. It is twelve feet deep. It was built up of riveted lengths of plates and bunk in entrenched sand. Its novelty lies less in its structure or material than in the difficulties which climate and surrounding conditions put in the way of its builders. It was extremely difficult to keep level because of the wind, which burrowed underneath the canal, scooping out the sand and letting a length of canal sink. Another difficulty was due to the pneqnal expansion of the steel plates, because the sun's rays affected the side of the canal nearer to it more than the side further away. The steel plates, sometimes buckled in consequence. In the loose sand foundation tools were readily lost and scorpions only too readily found, so that even the hardened Arabs would not work at night. All the painting had to be done at night because it was too hot during the day, and screens had to be put at intervals to protect the workmen against the sun’s rays in this “aun trap." The steel tube is now dug in. The Arabs, by the way, drank the machine oil besides anointing their bodies with it.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Le marché a présenté ce matin un aspect, sensiblement analogue à celui d'hier, c'est-àdire que les transactions ont été rares et sans importance, et de plus que la dépression signalée bier et avant-hier a persisté. On avait d'abord commencé par un peu de tapage, pour s'étourdir sans doute, mais sans antre conséquence appréciable. Quant aux fluctuations, elles se sont nécessairement ressenties de cet état de marasme; elles sont insignifiantes et indiquent plutôt une réaction, surtout pour les valeurs d'ordre secondaire, qui avaient au contraire bénéficié hier d'une tenne tant soit peu meilleure.

Parmi les valeurs dirigeantes, la Delta Light s'avance de 9 9/16 à 9 13/16 acheteurs, et l'Obligation Crédit Foncier Egyptien de 299 à 300 l'ancienne et de 253 à 253 ½ la nouvelle ; l'Agricole se maintient à 8 1/16, tandis que la National Bank fléchit légèrement de 20 1/8 vendeurs à 20 1/16.
L'Union Foncière revient également de 4 1/2 à 4 7/16.
Les Markets ont été l'objet d'une assez bonne demande au début, mais plus tard ils se sont tassés à 28 vendeurs, contre 27/6 hier.
Plus faible, la Delta Land rétrograde de 1 3/4 à 11 11/16, l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 21 à 20/6 et les Ritz Hotels de 17/32 à 1/2 acheteurs.

On a traité, en proportions d'ailleurs res. treintes et de façon intermittente, l'Agricole, les Ritz, les Markets, la Delta Land, l'Obligatión Foncier et le Comptoir. Ces derviers, traités d'abord à 2 3/8, sont revenus en clôture à 29/32 l'ancienne et 2 11/32 la nouvelle contre 2 1/4 et 2 5/16 hier.
Sur le reste de la cote il n'y a pas de changements à signaler..

Au milieu d'une pareille inaction, l'attention a naturellement été attirée par l'enchère publique demandée par M. M. Salinas à l'encontre de la Bourse and Banking : 3375 Ritz Hotels ont trouvé preneurs à 1/2, et 60 actions nouvelles de la Société des Immeubles de la Rue Chérif á £ 4 1/8. Pour les 75 Cassa di Sconto nouvelle émission qui faisaient aussi partie de l'enchère, elles n'ont trouvé d'acheteurs à aucun prix et restent ainsi ponr compte à la Bourse and Banking.

A propos c'est ce soir que doit avoir lieu l'assemblée de cette société convoquée pour la troisième fois. Tous les administrateurs y assisteront et devront s'expliquer sur leur gestion des affaires sociales. Cette société mort-née, pour ne pas faillir sans doute à son allure folâtre qui a déjà occasionné tant de surprises désagréables à ses actionnaires, a refusé à la presse. d'assister à la réunion.
Aussi avons-nous pris nos mesures en conséquence pour renseigner exactement nos lecteurs.

MM. Prazzica, Zombos et Avlonitis ont acheté à la halte Laurent, près de San Stefano, une parcelle de terrain de 70,000 pics carrés, à raison de P.T. 96 le pic, soit pour une somme globale de L.E. 67,200.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, Mercredi 11 Septembre. Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres est renseigné invarié à 4 pour cent..

Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a haussé avant-bier de 1/8 et hier de 1/4 à 82 1/8. L'Unifiée a haussé hier de 1/4 à 101 3/4. La National Bank a reperdu ce qu'elle avait gagné la veille à 20 1/4. L'Agricole a été soutenue 8 8 1/4, la Daïra à 12 3/4 et la Delta Light 19 3/4. A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a perdu 1 franc à 687. Les Lots Turcs se sont maintenus à leur cours de la veille à 166. La Banque d'Athènes a été ferme à 113.
Ici, malgré les quelques jours de repos dont a joui la Bourse, le marché a débuté ce matin avec les mêmes errements que la dernière semaine.

La séance a montré la même faiblesse que par le passé et le volume des transactions a été encore plus réduit. Naturellement on observe une rétrogradation quasi-générale des valeurs traitées, mais il ne faut pas trop s'en émotionner, car le mois de Septembre est réputé pour son inactivité dans tous les marchés financiers.
A cette cause, très passagère, s'ajoutent les liquidations suivies auxquelles certaines banques procèdent pour le compte de leurs. clients.

La dépréciation actuelle parait donc ne pas devoir durer outre mesure, et, les causes cessant, il n'est pas besoin d'être grand clerc pour prévoirun fort mouvement de reprise plus avant dans l'automne.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National Bank et l'Agricole sont restées invariées à 20 1/16 et 8 1/16 respectivement. La Cassa di Sconto est retombée à 36. La Banque d'O. rient s'améliore à 117.
La Delta Light est en léger progrès à 9 1/2 et la Ramleh Railway recule à 45/8.

Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire, peu traitées, reviennent à 200. La Daïra Sanieh mollit à 12 3/4. Le Crédit Foncier hausse à 685 et la fondateur s'affaisse à 700. La Wardan Estate se ressaisit à 4 1/4. L'Allotment, moins favorisée, s'alourdit à 2 1/4 et sa fondateur rétrograde à P.T. 58.
L'Union Foncière, atteinte comme les autres, s'inscrit en baisse à 4 7/16.

Les fondateurs Enterprise and Development se consolident 310 1/2. L'Agricole du Nil est en méilleare tendance à 195. La Société d'Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux est très ferte à 21/4 tandis que sa part se tasse à

P.T. 43. Les Heliopolis progressent a 248. La Brasserie des Pyramides faiblit à 85 et l'Anglo-American Nile à 2 1/2. Les Omnibus Automobiles ne sont pas mieux tenus à 2 3/16. La Frigorifique est en baisse à 3.
Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Nungovich tombentà 13 5/8 avec peu de transactions. Les Baehler se laissent influencer par l'allure du marché a 6 1/16-1/8. Les Ritz rétrogradent à 0 1/2-9/16.
Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land quoique active est peu soutenue & 1 11/16-3/4. Les Markets reculent à 27/6 et les Estates à 0 5/8. Il en est de même pour les Hooker a 0 7/16.
On s'occupe beaucoup en ce moment dans les milieux financiers italiens de la création d'une nouvelle institution de Crédit pour les opérations de Bourse.

Cette Institution aurait principalement pour fonction de prévenir les crises de Bourse, en acquérant des valeurs et pratiquant des reports, en appliquant aux valeurs mobilières les mêmes principes que les institutions de Crédit Foncier emploient pour leurs prêts sur immeubles.

Le bilan de la Bourse and Banking, arrêté à la date du 6 Août et qui a été communiqué à l'assemblée de vendredi, fait ressortir un sol. de en caisse de L.E. 184 et 599 millièmes. La valeur des terrains appartenant à la Société est représentée par 4,893 L.E., le compte des débiteurs divers de la Société par L.E.217,092, la valeur des titres en portefeuille au cours du 6 Août par L.E.20,254, celle de l'agencement par L.E.1,115 et enfin les pertes se soldent par L.E.42,530 et 489 millièmes.

La Ghezireh Mansions Ltd., propriétaire comme on sait de 10,000 m.c. de terrains à Ghezireh, a établi un projet de construction de 7 immeubles de rapport afin d'en tirer un revenu le plus rapidement possible. Pour se procurer les fonds nécessaires elle vient de créer 90 parts de L.E.4,000 chacune.
A en croire les devis, ces immeubles rapporteraient dès leur achèvement L.E.32,320, déduction faite des frais d'administration, impôts et imprévns, soit environ 9% du capital employé.
La construction de ces immeubles coûterait environ L.E.200,000.
Pour la semaine au 31 Août, les recettes de l’Egyptian Delta Light Railways Ltd. se sont élevées à 4,527 L.E. contre 4,197 L.E. pour la semaine 'correspondante en 1906, soit un excédent de 330 L.E.
Du ler Avril au 31 Août, le total des recettes a été de L.E.100,858 contre L.E.85319 en 1906, ce qui donne un surplus de L.E. 15,539 pour l'exercice actuel.

div.head: THE CASABLANCA SITUATION.
div.p: ARAB POSITION RECONNOITRED.
GENERAL DRUDE RECOVERING.
CASABLANCA, September 11.
General Drude is recovering. A French war balloon bas ascended here and reconnoitred the Arab position.
Admiral Philibert reports that all is quiet here and elsewhere. (Reuter)
CASABLANCA, September 11.

General Drude is well again. Yesterday was quiet. The Moors fired at the balloon bat their shots proved ineffective. Observations from the balloon state that the enemy has received reinforcements. (Havas)
BERLIN, September 11.
Prince von Buelow has decided to advance 250,000 marks to the German sufferers at Casablanca from the Imperial Treasury, subject to repayment by responsible parties. (Reuter)
BERLIN, September 11.
Prince von Buelow is understood to have decided that the Germans who have suffered losses at Casablanca should receive a compensation of 250,000 marks from the responsible parties. (Reuter)

div.head: TURCO-PERSIAN QUESTION.
div.p: THE NEW CABINET.
TEHERAN, September 11. An undated official report states that 100 Turkish infantry have occupied Gangachin, in north-west Urumia. The Turks are now occupy. ing -150 villages.
A deputation has waited upon the Shah, objecting to the composition of the new Cabinet.
. (Reuter)

div.head: A COLONIAL'S DENOUNCEMENT.
div.p: COMPACT WITH NEW FOUNDLAND.

St. John's, September 11. The Premier, Sir Robert Bond, in the course of an interview said that the modus-vivendi was a disgrace to British diplomacy and a shame. ful sacrifice of the Colony's interest.. Only his protests while in London prevented the Imperial Government from concluding an infinitely worse compact.
(Reuter)

div.head: KING ALFONSO.
div.p: OPERATION FOR ADENOIDS.
MADRID, September 11. The King has been operated on for adenoids.
(Reuter) SAINT SEBASTIEN, September 11. - King Alfonso has undergone an operation. His state is satisfactory.
(Havas)

div.head: GERMAN ARMY MANŒUVRES.
div.p: BERLIN, September 11. The Army manoeuvres are concluded. 80,000 troops were engaged. There is much divergence of opinion with regard to the operations, especially as to the shortage of fighting in close formation and to the extraordinary cavalry charges.
(Renter)

div.head: SURRENDER OF MORENGA.
div.p: BERLIN, September 11. : It is officially stated that Morenga made overtures for surrender to the German Governor, who replied that he would accept his submission and forgive him if he gave up his arms and live peaceably.
(Reutro)
MOTOR-CAR FATALITY.
FORLI, September 11. · Prince Wurëscki was killed in an automobile accident.
(Havas)

div.head: THE HAGUE CONFERENCE.
div.p: PRIZE COURT.
THE HAGUE, September 11.

The sub-Committee has adopted the resolution with regard to the establishment of a Prize Court. 26 representatives voted for the project. Brazil and Turkey voted against it, objecting to the distribution of judges. Russia, Japan, and 13 small states abstained from voting : Russia owing to the incomplete nature of the legislation with reference to prizes, and Japan because she considered that the influence of the scheme on national jurisdiction required the most careful consideration. (R.)

div.head: TSAR'S YACHT ASHORE.
div.p: HELSINGFORS, September 12.

The Tsar's yacht "Standart" went aground on submerged rocks to the west of Hangoe, in the Fininsh Archipelago, yesterday. She remains fast: lifeboats and seven torpedo boats are standing by. The Tsar and his family are remaining on board. (Reuter)

div.head: ST. LEGER STAKES.
div.p: LONDON, September, 11.
1. Wool Winder ; 2. Baltinglass ; 3 Acclaim. Won by 6 lengths. A neck between second and third.
The weather was delightful : the King was present. (Reuter)

div.head: HUSSEIN PASHA KAMEL.
div.p: MARSEILLES, September 11.
Prince Hussein Pasha Kamel has arrived.
(Havas)

div.head: RUSSO-JAPANESE TREATIES.
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, September 11.
The text of the Russo-Japanese treaties have been published here. (Reuter)

div.head: HOME CRICKET.
div.p: LONDON, September 11.
The match between South Africans and M.C.C. was drawn. (Reuter)

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
div.p: KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT
LIVERPOOL, September 5.
The demand for Egyptian Cotton still con tinues very limited, and quotations are reduced 1/16 plb. for all qualities.
In Futures only a limited business has been done, and the following are the latest quotations :—

American Futures. The Market this week has experienced sharp fluctuations. Opening quiet prices lost 7 points; yesterday and to-day, however, with renewed activity prices have recovered quickly, to-day's closing values being 4 @ 5 points above those of last Thursday.

The decline in the early part of the week was due to an entire absence on speculative interest, to a belief in better crop conditions ; and on account of the American markets having been closed for two days. The advance was the result of unfavorable Crop news accompanied by American buying orders. Apparently the weather is again hot and dry in the South and West, and there may also be some uneasiness about the Ginners report and the Bureau report, both to be issued next Monday.
The Crop moving late is. also, for the moment, a "Bullish” factor.
The latest prices are, delivery :—
September. 7.08 1/2 Dec./Jan. 6.81 April/May 6.81 Sept./Oct. 6.93 Jan/Feb. 6.79 1/2 May/June 6.81 1/2 Oct./Nov. 6.88 1/2 Feb./Mar. 6.80 Nov./Dec. 6.83 Mar./Apl. 6.80 1/2

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET
div.p: (FROM OUR FINANCIAL CORRESPONDENT),
London, September 6.

With the advent of September and the near approach of the harvest, interest in the money ontlook increases in intensity, and there is much speculation as to the demands that are likely to be made on our gold resources, and the possibilities of an increased Bank rate. It was twelve months ago next week that the first heavy consignment of gold amounting to over three millions, was made to America, and the immediate result was the raising of the Bank rate from to 3 ½ to 4 per cent. To-day our reserve is within £220,000 of last year's total, and there are no signs that any shipment of importance will be made across the Atlantic in the near future. The position here is being strengthened week by week, and it is very assuring to note that present indications point to the fact that the Egyptian demand is the only one likely to cause any anxiety. Assuming that the United States Treasurer will deal out his contributions to the banks with sufficient liberality as to meet all pressing needs on that side, we are confident that Egypt's requirements will be promptly met, without much inconvenience.

This week the return shows a further increase in the reserve of £204,827, bringing the total up to £24,149,000, and the proportion to liabilities is now 50 per cent., which is up to last year's level. There has been an expansion of £290,575 in the note circulation, and Public Deposits are down £1,344,000 owing to Government disbursements. Other Deposits, however, have increased by £1,067,337.
The discount market continues easy, and day loans were obtainable yestertay at 1 ½ per cent.
'The Bank secured £300,000 of the £700,000 bar gold available, the Continental demand causing the authorities to raise their buying price 5/8 of a penny. Bar gold is now quoted 77/10 1/8.
The silver market has been uncertain from day to day, but on the whole the tone is steady. The price has risen from 31 ¼ to 31,7/16.

The hopes of a revival in investment business are as elusive as have been our ho. pes of Summer this year. On several occasions the advent of a sunny day and a clear sky has led as to declare without a shadow of suspicion that at last the warm weather had arrived, but the following day our re putation as a prophet has been hopelessly ruined by the return of wintry conditions. Even so has it happened on the Stock Exchange. Members have from time to time been deluded by passing spurts of activity to swear that the future of stocks and sha res was assured, only to be promptly plunged into the depths of despondency again. Last week it certainly seemed as if a definite change for the better bad occurred, but the revival had an even shorter life than usual, and during the past few days absolute stagnation has again prevailed in most actions of the "House." It is all very disappointing. One hears on every hand the complaint "no business doing." One writer this morning says that it is no exaggeration to state that the whole of the business transacted yesterday could have been compressed into a quarter of an hour. The seriousness of such a state of things must be very obvious as regards brokers, whose office and other expenses are almost as heavy now as in the more prosperous times. It is to be earnestly hoped that we shall soon see a permanent change for the better.

The gilt-edged section was weak during the early part of the week and Consols showed a daily decline. They have since been steadier, but have not succeeded in recovering their previous loss. The closing prices last night were 81 ½ xd. for cash and 81 11/16 xd. for the October account. Today consols close 1/8 higher for cash.

The publication of the news last Monday that the agreement between Great Britain and Russia had been signed, gave a good start to the market for International Bonds, which opened very firm. Russians were especially favoured, and the fives closed with a gain of 1, whilst the fours were up. The demand, however, has not been sustained, and quotations now are below the best. Japanese issues are also rather quiet, and yesterday they shed 1/8 to ¼.
To-day Russian Fives have advanced ¼. Several Japanese issues are 1/8 to ¼ better.

The Market for these stocks has displayed few signs of life; dealings have been on a very small scale, and the tone has been irregular. The excellent list of traffic receipts which has been published might have been expected to stimulate interest, but it signally failed in this respect. The increases reported by several of the lines are very gratifying. In the case of the North Eastern the increase amounts to £21,600, which follows on a gain of £16,000 a year ago. The North Western has an increase of £21,000, on top of £8,000 in 1906, and the Great Western add £17,000 to last year's increase of £7,200. In no case has a decrease been reported.
There has been nothing doing in home rails to-day, and the tone is dull.
Wall Street has been a disturbing feature this week, and the upward movement noticeable in the American section here was checked

by the weak tendency on the other side, where, immediately there is a sign of an advance being made, profit taking is resorted to by professionals who control the market.

With few exceptions, however, the decline has not been of any importance. Yesterday Northern Pacifics gave way 2 1/2 to 125, Unions 1 1/8 to 131 1/2, Southern Pacific 1 1/2 to 86 3/4, and Baltimore and Ohio 1 1/4 to 92 3/4. Baltimore Preterence were firm, and advanced 2 to 86.
There has been a further rally in Americans to-day. Unions have relapsed 1 1/2 gained 4 1/4 at 135 ¾.

There has been absolutely nothing doing in the Egyptian Market during the past week, and prices are practically unchanged. Daira Sanieh have been as good as 13, but closed easier at 12 3/4. National Bank of Egypt remain steady at 20 1/4, and Agricultural Bank at 8 1/4. The preference of the latter have been in demand and have risen from 8 7/8 to 9 1/8 buyers, and mark as high as 9 1/4. The last issue of the 84 per cent. Debentures have been a better market at 88 ½-9, but close 85-7. Egyptian Estates are not so strong, and are quoted from Egypt at 11/16, whilst Delta Land and Investment are also easier at 1 3/4. Corporation of Western Egypt, after being & buyers, close dull at 9/16. Delta Preference (bearer) are & strong market with good buying at 9 3/4-10, and the registered shares are wanted at 9 7/16. Egyptian Markets are being bought by out side brokers, and the price has risen to 28/6, at one time being 29/- bid ; the prospect for these shares is considered very good. There is no further change in Salt and Soda, the price being very nominal at 7/8-1. Land Bank of Egypt are quoted 7 3/8-5/8, and Union Fonciere 4 1/2-3/4.

At the beginning of this week Kaffirs expe. rienced quite a revival, and although the demand subsequently slackened off, prices still show a slight advance on balance. Rand Mines have been as good as 5 1/8, East Rands 3 3/4, and South African Options 5. The tone was weaker yesterday, but for the most part the declines Tere fractional. Rand Mines closed 5.1/16, and East Rands 3 5/8. To-day mining shares have been neglected.
Egyptian mining shares continue to mark time. Nile valley are quoted 1/3 and Egyptian Mines Exploration 1/-.
The closing prices to-night are as follows :

div.p: DE "L'EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"

Le Supplement Commercial et Pinancier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" parait chaque Samedi a midi, de façon a pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autriobien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs ; les der-nières statistiques jusqu'a la veil:e de sa publi-cation : des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées a la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc

div.head: THE UNITED EGYPTIAN LANDS. LTD.
div.p: NOTICE TO SHAREHOLDERS.

In accordance with a resolution taken by the Board of Directors of this Company to make a Second Call of 5/- per Share on the Ordinary Shares, I hereby beg to notify Share-holders, that said Second Call of 5/- per share becomes payable on 28th. September 1907 at The National Bank of Egypt Alexandria & Cairo.
Call Notices will be duly issued to Share holders who must pay the amounts due by them to the Bank on the above-mentioned date
I. DES CLAYES.
Secretary in Egypt.

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement OF THE "Egyptian Gazette."
div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the lates statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For Further particulars apply to the Manager the "Egyptian Gazette."
